title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 10, 2019).

PG&E cut power to about 700,000 households and businesses in northern and central California, aiming to avert the type of deadly infernos that killed dozens last year and propelled the utility into bankruptcy court.

Apple pulled an app that enabled Hong Kong protesters to track police activity, a move that came after criticism in Chinese state media.

The NBA, in its standoff with Beijing, is defying China's apology playbook for businesses that run afoul of the government.

Fed officials grew more worried at last month's meeting that slowing global growth could sap domestic hiring and economic activity.

Employer demand for workers softened this summer, as job openings fell from a year earlier for the third straight month in August.

American Airlines said it expects that Boeing's 737 MAX will remain out of service until January.

U.S. stocks rose, with the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq climbing 0.7%, 0.9% and 1%, respectively.

AT&T agreed to sell its Puerto Rican and U.S. Virgin Islands businesses, allowing the firm to pare its debt.

Nissan said it has limited the duties of Hari Nada, a former aide to Ghosn.

Target's chief merchant, Mark Tritton, resigned from the retailer to take the top job at Bed Bath & Beyond.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 10, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
